The Trump Organization said on Friday it was vetting new business structures aimed at transferring management control to three of President-elect Donald Trump's children and a team of executives.The Trump Organization said in a statement it was planning to transfer control of the portfolio of businesses to Donald Trump Jr
column2: Ivanka Trump
column3: Eric Trump and other executives.Earlier on Friday
column4: the three Trump children - the oldest of Trump's five children - were also named as members of Trump's Presidential Transition Team Executive Committee.  ""This is a top priority at the organization and the structure that is ultimately selected will comply with all applicable rules and regulations
column5: a spokesperson for the Trump Organization said in a statement.Federal conflict-of-interest law does not apply to the president
column6: but most White House occupants in the last few decades have voluntarily placed their assets in a blind trust to avoid any suggestion of impropriety.Experts in government ethics said that giving over control to Trump's children would do virtually nothing to prevent potential conflicts of interest
column7: since there's usually no daylight between one's personal interest and the interest of one's immediate family members.

column1: It doesn't meet any of the standards of a blind trust if the kids are running the company
column2: said Kenneth Gross
column3: a Washington lawyer who specializes in advising political clients on compliance and ethics.Gross noted that the official transition team roles that Ivanka Trump
column4: Donald Trump Jr and Eric Trump now have would appear to complicate matters further.""If they're going to be involved in government functions -  and they're starting down that road - and running the business
column5: that's going to make it very difficult to separate the government and business functions and deal with the conflicts of interest
column6: Gross said.

column1: All three children already have roles in the Trump Organization
column2: according to the company's website. Ivanka Trump is executive vice president of development and acquisitions
column3: charged with domestic and global expansion of the company's real estate interests.Donald Trump Jr is an executive vice president
column4: and works to expand the company's real estate
column5: retail
column6: commercial
column7: hotel and golf interests nationally and internationally. Eric Trump is executive vice president of development and acquisitions
column8: responsible for new project acquisition
column9: development and construction globally.

column1: Typically
column2: a blind trust involves turning over assets to an independent financial manager with no prior relationship to the owner. In addition
column3: a blind trust derives its name from the idea that the owner would no longer know what assets are sold or bought. For instance
column4: someone with extensive stock holdings would have no way of knowing which companies' shares he or she still owned in a blind trust.Trump's portfolio includes interests in hundreds of limited liability companies
column5: many overseas
column6: as well as numerous real estate properties both domestic and foreign.Short of selling the entire Trump empire
column7: experts said
column8: he will find it difficult to create a trust sufficiently ""blind"" to avoid the possibility of any conflicts. (Reporting by Emily Stephenson
column9: David Lawder and Joseph Ax; Editing by Eric Beech and Leslie Adler)"	['Trump']	[]

| CHICAGO
CHICAGO Illinois Governor Bruce Rauner reported personal income of more than $188.1 million in 2015

column4: a Republican
column5: and his wife
column6: Diana

column9: though no details were released on the source of those profits.""I believe as the good book says to whom much has been given from whom much is expected in return
column10: Rauner said at a news conference when asked about his tax returns.Rauner
column11: who has led a fight against Democrats controlling Illinois' legislature in the country's longest-running state fiscal impasse

column13: campaign records show.Illinois has not had a full operating budget for 17 months.

column1: Republicans netted four seats in the Illinois House and two seats in the state Senate in Tuesday's elections

column1: Because the Rauners' assets are in a blind trust

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKBN13628S	Trump says he's considering keeping parts of Obamacare: WSJ	"

President-elect Donald Trump told the Wall Street Journal he is considering retaining parts of President Barack Obama's healthcare law including provisions letting parents keep adult children up to age 26 on insurance policies and barring insurers from denying coverage to people with pre-existing conditions.The Republican businessman during the U.S. presidential campaign called for repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act
column2: also known as Obamacare
column3: and labeled the 2010 law ""a disaster.""In an interview published on Friday
column4: his first since winning Tuesday's election
column5: Trump told the Journal a big reason for his shift was his meeting at the White House on Thursday with Obama
column6: who suggested areas of the Affordable Care Act to preserve.""I told him I will look at his suggestions
column7: and out of respect
column8: I will do that
column9: Trump said.""Either Obamacare will be amended

column1: Some Republican lawmakers and advisers have recommended keeping those two provisions in place even if they are able to repeal the law in Congress
column2: as they have attempted to do for years.The law has enabled millions of Americans who previously had no health insurance to obtain coverage
column3: but Republicans oppose it and call it a government overreach.

column1: Other urgent priorities during his first few weeks as president
column2: Trump said
column3: would be deregulating financial institutions to allow ""banks to lend again
column4: and securing the U.S. border against drugs and illegal immigrants.Asked whether he would pursue a campaign promise to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate defeated Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton over her use of a private email server while secretary of state
column5: Trump told the paper: ""It's not something I've given a lot of thought
column6: because I want to solve healthcare
column7: jobs
column8: border control
column9: tax reform.""

column1: Trump also told the Journal he would create jobs through infrastructure projects and improved trade deals
column2: and would preserve American jobs by potentially imposing tariffs on the products of U.S. companies that relocated overseas. (Writing by Eric Beech; Editing by David Alexander and Will Dunham)"	['Clinton'

column27: a Rust Belt state that leans Democrat in presidential elections but which flipped to Trump on Tuesday. ""I know he'll build the wall. I know he'll take care of the Syrian refugee problem. I know he'll get rid of Obamacare. There is not a chance in hell he won't do those things

column2: Trump will have to accept limits and compromises on some of his plans. Many Republicans
column3: for example
column4: are wary of his proposals to scrap trade deals and boost spending on infrastructure improvements.Some of his plans have already been rolled back.Trump faces his highest expectations on the issue of immigration

column6: and temporarily banning Muslims from entering the country.But he recently indicated he would at first deport only criminal undocumented immigrants

Mark Morris

column1: I think it is a great blueprint for everything that he has promised

column3: a former Republican congressional staffer. The Hensarling blueprint would primarily allow banks to choose between complying with Dodd-Frank or meeting tougher capital requirements - primarily to maintain a ratio of tangible equity to leverage exposure of 10 percent. It would also reorganize the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau
column4: throw out the Volcker Rule restricting banks from making speculative investments and eliminate the authority of the Financial Stability Oversight Council to designate non-banks as ""systemically important."" It also differs from the Dodd-Frank legislation in the way it treats insolvent banks. Hensarling says his approach will prevent taxpayer dollars from being used to bail out failed institutions.

column1: Alongside Obamacare
column2: Dodd-Frank is considered one of Democratic President Barack Obama's signature domestic policies.The most senior Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee
column3: Sherrod Brown
column4: has been a vocal defender of it
column5: as has liberal firebrand Senator Elizabeth Warren. That means a Dodd-Frank revamp could stall in one chamber of Congress. Senate rules allow a single member to block a bill from proceeding to a vote.Trump said last May that he would dismantle Dodd-Frank
column6: primarily because the law makes it hard for banks to loan money.

column1: NOGALES
column2: Mexico Donald Trump's election victory and his plans to crack down on illegal immigration is so troubling for the groups of men gathered just south of a rusty

That could continue in coming months even as some like Lopez decide they no longer want to live in the United States.During fiscal year 2016

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-rural-idUSKBN13625Q	In rural-urban divide

column1: By Nick Carey
| JANESVILLE
column2: Wisc.

column1: JANESVILLE
column2: Wisc. Semi-retired Wisconsin pig farmer John Lader does not think much of Donald Trump as a messenger
column3: but voted for what he described as the Republican president-elect's message of change and economic hope for America.""The last few years
column4: there hasn't been much optimism and hope among working people in rural areas in this country

column7: who lives in the farmland outside the southern Wisconsin city of Janesville.Around 65 miles (105 km) to the northeast in the state's biggest city of Milwaukee
column8: Jose Boni
column9: who cleans offices at a local university and rents out several homes
column10: heard a different message: Trump's plan to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexican border and vow to deport the estimated 11 million immigrants who are in the United States illegally
column11: most of whom are Hispanic. ""He doesn't care about our community or working people
column15: an Ecuador-born U.S. citizen.The different worlds of Lader and Boni help illustrate the rural-urban divide that was critical to the outcome of Tuesday's U.S. presidential election.A country once defined by regional voting now is more clearly divided by the differences between rural and urban voters. The combination of a strong Trump turnout in the countryside and a weak showing by Democrat Clinton in the cities went a long way toward deciding the election.Rural and small-town working-class white voters
column16: who already tended to vote Republican
column18: where black and Hispanic voters are concentrated along with college-educated voters

column24: while Clinton bested Trump by about 7 percentage points in urban areas

column9: but Clinton was around 240
column10: 000 votes short of Obama's 2012 tally. She ended up around 24
column11: 000 votes behind Trump in the state.""Those couple hundred thousand Democratic voters for whatever reason decided not to vote
column13: a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. ""They stayed home
column14: and Wisconsin went Republican. I think that was the pattern around the country.""

column1: WASHINGTON Republican U.S. President-elect Donald Trump has removed New Jersey Governor Chris Christie as leader of his transition team
column2: handing the reins over to Vice President-Elect Mike Pence
column3: a former U.S. lawmaker with deep Washington ties
column4: the New York Times reported on Friday. The Times
column5: citing several sources close to the transition team
column6: said Trump told advisers he wanted to use Pence's contacts to move the transition process along. NBC News also reported the handover
column7: which came one week after two former Christie associates were found guilty in the New Jersey ""Bridgegate"" scandal.

column1: (Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Christie'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-michigan-idUSKBN13621W	A discontented Michigan town: America should have seen Trump coming	"
By Jonathan Allen
| ALGONAC
column2: Mich.

column1: ALGONAC
column2: Mich. Back in April
column3: there were already early signs in this quiet Michigan town of the rural American discontent that helped propel Donald Trump to election victory
column4: even if it was underestimated by the Washington establishment
column5: pollsters and Hillary Clinton's campaign.On a return visit after Tuesday's election
column6: Reuters found that many of Algonac's 4
column7: 000 residents were jubilant that Trump had captured the White House
column8: although there were also echoes of what some people said seven months ago: that he is an uncertain
column9: high-stakes gamble.But the bare fact of his success drew only shrugs: Who else did city folks really expect would win?Reuters first visited this town on a bend of the St. Clair River in April after results from the Republican and Democratic parties' primary elections suggested it might be a hotbed of the  dissatisfaction with the status quo that would become a dominant force by November. (reut.rs/2fAVJQY)It was a town in a county in a state that all disproportionately turned out in the primaries for the unexpected outsider candidates: the Republican Trump
column10: a rich real-estate developer and television star who had never held political office; and democratic socialist Bernie Sanders
column11: a  U.S. senator from Vermont who had emerged as Clinton's closest rival for the Democratic Party nomination.Trump went on to win his party's nomination
column12: while Sanders was beaten by Clinton. Even though they came at the problem from very different perspectives
column13: both men had fired up a town that was in a sour mood
column14: striking a chord with their talk of a rigged economic system and their loud disgust at the decline of American manufacturing.Algonac leans Republican
column17: it took no time at all to find Trump fans
column18: and only a little longer to find Sanders fans. But it took days of asking around to find someone with a warm word for Clinton. On Tuesday
column19: the vote in Algonac was 68 percent for Trump

column1: Residents of Algonac can easily list the relatives and neighbors who have struggled with the painful decline of manufacturing or who were forced to move after auto factories with well paid union jobs an hour away in the Detroit area shut down or moved abroad.
Older residents recall decades back when Algonac was still a proud self-sufficient manufacturing hub
column2: employing scores of locals at the Chris-Craft factory
column3: which turned out photogenic wooden boats that remain prized by wealthy collectors. Pete Beauregard has turned the factory into a harbor club where the town's summer visitors stow their boats. ""The rural area is going to want to be heard
column4: he said
column5: delighting in Trump's victory.Up the road
column6: Jay DeBoyer was in a dive bar he had worked in as a younger man
column7: drinking an afternoon glass of water and dressed in a suit he had worn to deliver St. Clair County's final elections results to the courthouse in his role as county clerk.""The center of the country is what put Donald Trump in office
column8: he said. ""If the economy's okay
column9: they shut their mouths and go to work
column11: describing the sort of people who live in places like Algonac
column12: where 97 percent of residents are white.

column1: But if you start to smack them
column2: when you start telling the guys working in a coal mine in West Virginia
column3: 'For the good of the country
column4: we're going to put you out of a job
column5: for the good of cleaner air we're going to put you out of a job
column6: ' then you start to create a constituency of people that fall into a category of 'the enemy of my enemy is my friend.'""CRUDE TERMS FOR CLINTON

column1: Mentioning Clinton
column2: a former secretary of state
column3: U.S. senator and first lady
column4: tended to draw scorn among Algonac residents in April
column5: even among some Democrats who said they viewed her as untrustworthy.Her election loss and emotional concession speech this week appeared not to soften this
column6: with some expressing their ill-feeling in crude terms.

column1: Trump That Bitch
column2: reads a tall wooden sign alongside the main road into town
column3: evoking a familiar anti-Clinton slogan among Trump fans.Seeing it being photographed
column4: Paul Paulus
column6: wandered out from the building where he was regreasing old tractors to boast he had built it entirely himself. Some of his neighbors
column7: particularly women
column8: had told Reuters on both visits that
column9: even if they disliked Clinton
column10: they despaired at the insults and coarse language that Trump and his fans had reveled in. Paulus described his victory over such qualms.""They had tried to get the township to take it down
column12: smiling at the memory of the fight as he looked up at his sign. ""But the township said it's not coming down as 'bitch' is not a bad word. It's a female dog.""Jan Evans
column13: a devout 64-year-old Christian who runs a store making slogan t-shirts for the local schools' sports teams
column14: said she thought there were better ways to talk about people. But she sympathized with the sort of anxiety that moved people to support Trump.She recently learned that her monthly health insurance premiums under Obamacare
column15: a healthcare law that Trump has said he will repeal and replace
column16: would go from $120 to $357. But she worried that Trump's victory would not help
column17: either; she did not know what his healthcare plans were as he has not given details.She said that when she voted
column18: she filled out down-ballot lines for local and state elections and left the presidential vote until the end to give her more time to think. ""Neither one really deserved it
column19: she said of Clinton and Trump. Her pen hovered for quite a while
column20: but she declined to say where on the ballot it landed.""Everybody
column24: she said of Trump's victory. ""But this is the change?"" (Editing by Jason Szep and Frances Kerry)"	['Sanders'
